mean.translation[0].definitions[0].defin: to have or represent a particular meaning
mean.translation[0].definitions[0].examp: The report fails to define what is meant by the term ‘key issues’.
This light means you’re running low on fuel.
mean.translation[0].definitions[0].note_: In written English, people often prefer to say that something indicates something is the case, rather than using mean:
The light indicates that fuel supplies are low.
mean.translation[0].definitions[1].defin: to intend a particular meaning when you say something
mean.translation[0].definitions[1].examp: It’s pretty obvious what she means.
Oh yeah! I see what you mean (=I understand what you are trying to say).
What I mean is, I don’t feel alone anymore (=used to explain more about what you have said).
‘I didn’t really like him.’ 'I know what you mean, I didn’t get on with him either  (=used to say you understand and have had the same experience).
‘In three hours’ time, I’ll be a free man.‘ ’How do you mean (=used to ask someone to explain what they have just said)?'
Do you mean you’ve changed or Chris has changed?
I want to buy her something really special, if you know what I mean.
do/if you know/see what I mean?
We’re still married but living apart in the same house, if you see what I mean.
do/if you know/see what I mean?
I meant we’d have to leave early – that’s all.
mean.translation[0].definitions[2].defin: to intend to do something or intend that someone else should do something
mean.translation[0].definitions[2].examp: I’m sure she didn’t mean it (=she did not intend to upset or hurt someone).
He may sound a bit rude at times, but he means well (=intends to be helpful or kind, even if it does not seem like that).
I wasn’t criticizing you, I really meant it for the best (=wanted to be helpful, although my actions had the wrong effect).
I’m sure he didn’t mean any harm.
I’ve been meaning to ask you if you want to come for a meal next week.
I didn’t mean to upset you.
I didn’t mean this to happen at all.
I never meant you to find out.
I didn’t mean for her to get hurt.
mean for somebody to do something
mean.translation[0].definitions[3].defin: to have a particular result or involve something
mean.translation[0].definitions[3].examp: The merger will mean the closure of the company’s Sydney office.
Don’t let him see you. It will only mean trouble.
Dieting also means being careful about which foods you buy.
The high cost of housing means that many young people can’t afford to buy a house.
My new job will mean travelling all over the world.
mean.translation[0].definitions[4].defin: if a name, word etc means something to you, you are familiar with it or you understand it
mean.translation[0].definitions[4].examp: He said his name was ‘Randall’ but it meant nothing to me  (=I was not familiar with it).
Does the name Bryce mean anything to you?
You need to use analogies which will mean something to the reader.
mean.translation[0].definitions[5].defin: to be serious about what you are saying or writing
mean.translation[0].definitions[5].examp: With children, if you say ‘no’, you have to mean it.
I meant what I said earlier.
You don’t really mean that, do you?
mean.translation[0].definitions[6].defin: used for saying how important someone or something is to you
mean.translation[0].definitions[6].examp: The medal meant a lot to him.
Time meant nothing (=it was not important) to me while I was travelling.
Of course the relationship meant something to me.
He meant the world to her.
mean the world to somebody/mean everything to somebody
I know how much your work means to you.
mean.translation[0].definitions[7].defin: to be a sign that something is true or will happen
mean.translation[0].definitions[7].examp: Finding a lump does not necessarily mean you have cancer.
Clear skies mean that it will be a cold night.
Just because he’s been in prison, it doesn’t mean that he’s violent.
mean.translation[0].definitions[8].defin: used to say that a particular person or thing is the one that you are talking about, pointing to etc
mean.translation[0].definitions[8].examp: I meant the pink dress, not the red one.
mean.translation[0].note_box[0].items[0]: Mean is not used in the progressive in any of its senses, except for sense 3 You say
mean.translation[1].definitions[0].examp: That was a mean thing to do.
I felt a bit mean asking him to help.
It’s a mean trick to play on someone.
It was mean of him not to invite her.
Don’t be so mean to her!
mean.translation[1].definitions[1].defin: not wanting to spend money, or not wanting to use much of something
mean.translation[1].definitions[1].examp: He’s too mean to buy a present for his wife.
He’s always been mean with his money.
It was supposed to be garlic bread, but they’d been a bit mean with the garlic.
mean.translation[1].definitions[2].examp: The study involved 60 patients with a mean age of 58.2 years.
The mean annual rainfall was 852 mm.
mean.translation[1].definitions[3].examp: She walked briskly through the mean and dirty streets.
mean.translation[3].definitions[0].examp: Analysts’ mean estimate is for earnings of 33 cents a share.
mean.translation[4].definitions[0].examp: The GDP of this state was 32% below the mean for the country as a whole.
